I'm in Oxnard, CA.

And what you say squares with something I remember him =
mentioning: he said that the family told him this was a "family heirloom", =
so maybe it has the kind of blade you mention.  When I looked at it, I wond=
ered whether it had been a bigger blade at some point.  I actually "know" a=
lmost nothing about blades, although I am fascinated by them, but something=
 about the proportions seemed a bit like that to me.  

I'd love it if some=
one knew how to remove the hilt and look at the nakago(correct word?) to se=
e if there are any identifying markings on it.

Thanks for your response!

=
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, <nixe@...> wrote:
>
> Sue
> 
> where a=
re you located? if one of us are in your area we could arrange to see it. T=
he tanto is a Navy officer's dirk, they were made from early 1900's through=
 WWII. Some had hand made blades but most had machine made blades. If you g=
oogle Japanese Navy Dirk you might see others like yours. Not sure what els=
e you need, let us know
> 
> mark
> nixe@...
